content.webTitle: King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard: We should have started a taxi service

fields.headline: King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard: We should have started a taxi service
fields.bodyText: “What is psych?” asks Stu Mackenzie. “Is it psyche? Is it psychedelic? If it’s an exploratory approach to music then perhaps we are. If it’s about creating huge walls of glistening, phased-out guitars then we are not. I’ve always felt more like a garage band than anything. We don’t write songs about space, either.” For a moment there, it felt as though the psych-soul-surf-fuzz-garage-space rock-jazz-DIY-shamans King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard had slowed down on their deranged release schedule – nothing for eight whole months. “Did we?” laughs singer Mackenzie. Yes. “Maybe,” the emperor Gizzard replies. “Maybe, not sure. We finished off Quarters! in October so it feels like we kept busy.” But it didn’t come out till May! Where could we turn to for our wigged-out Aus psych? Both Pond and Tame Impala were offering us moments of mind-melting musical metamorphosis, but even so … eight months? “I wanted to make a record where I didn’t have to yell,” says Mackenzie, “as well as exploring some longer, repetitive song structures.” Four tracks, four quarters, each one precisely 10.10 minutes long, each one an extended jam teeming with melodies, the occasional trickle of water, space funk, laughter like Pink Floyd and deliciously unfussy grooves. “I also didn’t want to use any brutal guitar pedals or sing through blown-out guitar amps as I usually would.” As noted, King Gizzard’s music (sometimes) sounds so simple you can almost hear the workings. “It is jam-based and has minimal overdubbed parts,” finishes the singer, adding that the record was more of an experiment than anything. One time I took acid, and all the hairs on my arm lit up like Sunderland bridge, and time started folding in on itself backwards. This is almost exactly what the final track on Quarters! – the gentle, trippy, playful Lonely Steel Sheet Flyer – sounds like. Except it doesn’t. Of course. “Music is exploratory for me,” says Mackenzie, whose dad would sing him to sleep with Neil Young and Paul Kelly songs. He later graduated to 1960s psych garage compilations such as Pebbles and Nuggets, and on to “weirder, 1970s eastern stuff” like Erkin Koray and Flower Travellin’ Band. “I feel like there are a million ways to make music or make a record that I haven’t explored yet. Not to mention so many instruments to learn, music to hear, cultures to explore.” For a band that started as a side project in 2011, the Wizards have been astonishingly fertile since. “We were friends before King Gizzard originated playing in a jumble of other bands around Melbourne,” says Mackenzie. “Sometimes I wish we had started a taxi service – could have gotten in there before Uber.” Instead they have released six albums and a range of 12-inchers on multi-coloured wax. Standouts include the disturbing Satan Speeds Up, the cuddly psychosis of Hot Wax, and the one that made the rock world stir out of its torpor for three seconds: the mighty, mighty 16-minute-long Head On/Pill, blast after blast after blast of pre-emptive guitar lines and fuzzy bliss. “Language to me is music and there is a lot of rhythm and melody in the way people talk. Music and lyrics are one and the same. I’m not sure where the lyrics come from but, for me, it is surely the same part of the brain as the music.” There are videos extolling the virtues of Vegemite (“It’s delicious!”) in the same way the Flaming Lips once extolled the virtues of Vaseline. The parallels don’t stop there. Like the Lips years before Coyne started rolling around in giant hamster balls, King Gizzard are on a dizzying trip to the centre of psychedelia (Arthur Brown, Syd Barrett, The Exploding Plastic Inevitable, Gong), cocooning themselves in spaced-out neighing, decaying, vertiginous guitar lines and engorged melodies that demand to beviewed, Disney-style, through a dodecahedral prism of light. In other places, their music is bubblegum pop. Bubblegum like Archie on acid. It seems like only a year ago that this unpredictable seven-piece were giving away all their music for free because it felt like a “futuristic thing to do”. Oh wait, it was only a year ago. “We don’t make any money off digital sales anyway,” says Mackenzie. “Who does? So why not give it to them for free?” Since then King Gizzard have been touring the world – the US, Australia, their coming appearance at Glastonbury – in a haze of oil-streaked light shows, strobes and psychedelic dressage. “Outdoor shows scare me,” confesses their singer. “I’ve always felt a lot more at home playing under a roof with the sound bouncing around the room.” Which explains “the dawn of Gizzfest”, the band’s two-day pysch jam on their home turf, where like-minded bands crowd together to blow minds. It smacks of a scene. “There are bands we play with regularly who play a similar style of music,” acknowledges Mackenzie. “I’m usually the most influenced by the music my friends’ bands are making. Does that make a scene? There sure is some fantastic and inspiring music coming from Australia all the time, and that is the most important thing.” As to how they manage to get through so many live shows, what fuels the madness? “For half the band, it’s kale and quinoa. For the other it’s Red Bull and Twisties.” Everything is light and colour and sound in King Gizzard’s world. • King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard are touring North America and Europe, playing Glastonbury festival on 26 June
